Article Title: Dash for proof, but can you swear by it?: Delhi drivers use dashcams to settle traffic disputes safely
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Everything is calm as you drive late at night on a quiet Delhi street - until a scooter suddenly cuts across your car. You slam the brakes, your heart racing. For a moment, you picture the worst. What if the rider is injured? What if someone blamed you? What if it became your word against everyone else's?For Rejimon CK, founder of Dwarka Forum and resident of Sector 22, this was a real scenario in Dec when his car collided with a two-wheeler. The riders got aggressive and blamed him. But Rejimon had a dashcam recording and the footage showed exactly what happened. "I used it to file a police complaint," he said.Though he has been using a recording device placed on his car dashboard for only two years, he had also rigged up his old phone as a dashcam for five years. "In an accident, it's important to have proof. I now use both front and rear cams. Once a car hit me from behind, and again the dashcam proved I wasn't at fault. It also rids you of guilt when you know you're right," he said.Rejimon's experience highlights a reality on city roads. This year, there has been a daily average of 15 accidents, some fatal, others causing injuries. Four-wheelers may be at fault more often, but not every crash is so clear.That is where a dashcam can change the narrative.But the question is: should every car have a dashcam? "These devices can be very useful in forensics if the footage survives a crash because it can help establish the cause of accidents and is admissible as electronic evidence in court. People should use dashcams," suggested professor Triveni Singh, an ex-IPS officer.Cyberlaw expert Dr Karnnika A Seth, a Supreme Court advocate, confirmed that dashcam footage was admissible in court under Section 63 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, which recognises electronic records as documents if certain conditions are met. "The device must be reliable, the recording untampered. A certificate explaining how the footage was created and stored is required," she explained, adding that a forensic expert's affidavit, along with the user's affidavit, is necessary. According to her, if these conditions are satisfied, such footage can serve as strong evidence in accident and insurance disputes.But, Singh added, "Low-quality devices are risky since the data may not be retrievable or verifiable, rendering it inadmissible. I've seen cases where clear footage proved the other party's fault, showing their value. More people should use dashcams, but only good-quality ones, ideally with automatic cloud backup to avoid data loss."A dashcam is an idea still catching up but there are many who testify to its usefulness. Rajeev Kakaria of Greater Kailash I said, "I've been using a dashcam for years. In the city, it protects me from road rage or traffic disputes, and in the mountains, I use it to capture scenic drives. Once a cop flagged me down after the light turned red mid-way. The moment I showed him my dashcam footage, he had to let me go."Dashcams have also captured incidents that went viral online. A hit-and-run on the Defence Colony-Lajpat Nagar flyover sparked outrage after a reckless Swift driver crashed into an auto and nearly hit a scooter before speeding away. Another motorist shared his dashcam footage on Reddit, bringing public attention to the reckless driving. As a traffic officer admitted, "In some cases, motorists do share dashcam footage. Any form of surveillance assists and adds value to the investigation."Dashcams are impartial - they record everything. If the driver is at fault, the footage can be used against them. They record speeding beyond the limit, rash driving, signal jumps and distracted driving. Anil Chikara, a transport expert, said, "These devices don't just help check the behaviour of other drivers, but also encourage self-discipline since the driver knows he or she can be held accountable for a mistake. "With GPS features, they log exact speed and location, providing clarity in disputes. Dashcams protect the innocent and expose violators alike. However, there's a catch: most dashcams automatically overwrite old footage after a few days, depending on the installed memory card's storage capacity. Drivers who want to preserve evidence longer need to download the recordings or back them up externally on a computer, memory card or cloud storage.There are different types of dashcams. Some record only the front view, while others capture both the front and rear, which many drivers prefer for its wider coverage. Dealers say awareness is growing, but the trend is uneven. Mid-range models cost Rs 8,000-Rs 9,000 and offer features like high-quality video and GPS tracking. Many car brands, including Hyundai and Toyota, now offer dashcams as accessories. Those with advanced sensors can record clearly even in low light.A seller added, "Dashcams do more than capture video of accidents. They help with insurance claims, protect parked cars, settle road rage or traffic disputes and encourage safer driving."As the trend catches on, industry is racing to keep up, turning what was once a niche accessory into a booming business. As per an Economic Times report, the business, valued at just over Rs 887 crore in 2023, is projected to cross Rs 3,106 crore by 2032, growing at an annual rate of 15-18%. Adoption could reach 5% of car owners within the next two to three years.
Article Summary: Dashcams can be very useful in forensics if the footage survives a crash. They can help establish the cause of accidents and is admissible as electronic evidence in court. But low-quality devices are risky since the data may not be retrievable or verifiable, rendering it inadmissible.

Article Text: LONDON: A new dark web portal to recruit spies for Britain's foreign intelligence agency, MI6, from countries such as Russia will be launched in the UK on Friday. Article Title: TOI on Campus: The interweaving of art, textiles and AI

NAVI MUMBAI: Brinda Miller, fine artist and chairperson of Kala Ghoda Association, said artificial intelligence (AI) will be much in use even in the traditional way of textile making in India, which is good, but it can have a few detrimental effects. Miller, who was addressing students of National Institute of Fashion Technology (NIFT) at their Kharghar campus, said art and textiles have long been interwoven since ancient India, and now AI will be added on to embellish this evolving fabric.This was a part of the lecture series of TOI on Campus, and the topic at NIFT was 'The Art And Science Of Textiles'."Before becoming an artist, I had studied textiles at the J J School of Art in Mumbai around 40 years ago. More than the attire, it is a symbol of transition (from past to present, to future)," said Miller.On the future of textiles, she elaborated that even the oldest looms of Kanchipuram in Tamil Nadu, are adapting certain AI features now to improve their efficiency. "AI revolutionizes logistics, which is why the traditional textiles are also using AI, which also helps you to become more creative and artistic," said Miller.She said there is a possibility of using LED lights in created fabrics, with the help of AI. Or fabrics that change colours depending on the wearer's body temperature. The Atlantic Ocean may witness one of meteorology‚Äôs rarest and most intriguing phenomena this week as Tropical Storm Humberto and a nearby developing system, Invest 94L, move closer together. These storms could interact through the Fujiwhara Effect, a complex dynamic where two cyclonic systems orbit around a shared center. While more common in the western Pacific, this effect occasionally occurs in the Atlantic, last seen in 2023 with Tropical Storms Philippe and Rina. Such interactions can dramatically affect storm trajectories, intensities, wind speeds, and landfall possibilities, significantly complicating forecasts. The Fujiwhara Effect can result in one storm dominating, merging with the other, or creating unpredictable rotations, making it a key focus for meteorologists and vulnerable coastal communities.The Fujiwhara Effect is a meteorological phenomenon that occurs when two cyclones or hurricanes spinning in the same direction come within roughly 900 miles of each other. Upon reaching this proximity, the storms begin to orbit a shared central point, creating a ‚Äúdancing‚Äù motion.This movement is not a simple rotation; each storm circulates around the midpoint, much like two ice skaters holding hands and spinning in a synchronized pattern.Typically, the stronger storm dominates, pulling the weaker system into its circulation, potentially absorbing it entirely. In rarer cases, storms of nearly equal strength can merge, forming a single, more powerful cyclone. This effect was first observed and documented in the 1920s by Dr. Sakuhei Fujiwhara, a Japanese meteorologist who studied interactions of vortices in water and their implications for larger atmospheric systems.The Fujiwhara Effect is more commonly observed in the western Pacific due to the higher frequency of cyclones forming in close proximity. In the Atlantic, simultaneous storms close enough to interact are less frequent, which is why such occurrences are notable. The last recorded Atlantic Fujiwhara event took place in September 2023, when Tropical Storms Philippe and Rina briefly engaged in a complex orbital pattern before one storm overtook the other.The rarity of this effect in the Atlantic adds a layer of unpredictability to hurricane season forecasting. When two storms interact, standard models may struggle to accurately predict track, intensity, and potential landfall, making early warnings and continuous monitoring essential.Currently, Tropical Storm Humberto (formerly known as Invest 93L) is moving west-northwest across the Atlantic with sustained winds of 40 mph. Forecasts suggest Humberto could strengthen into a hurricane by the weekend. Meanwhile, Invest 94L, which is likely to become Tropical Storm Imelda, is developing nearby.Meteorologists are particularly focused on these two systems because the potential Fujiwhara interaction could dramatically alter 94L‚Äôs path. While Humberto is expected to remain mostly offshore, its gravitational influence on 94L could either push it toward land or deflect it, significantly affecting risk zones along the US East Coast. This interdependence highlights how unpredictable tropical storm behavior can become when multiple systems are involved.When storms enter a Fujiwhara interaction, they rotate around a shared center rather than simply around each other. The outcomes of this interaction can vary:In rare cases, two similar-strength storms merge, creating a single, more powerful cyclone.These dynamics complicate forecasting models, as standard prediction tools struggle to account for the rotational and merging behaviors of interacting systems. Satellite imagery, historical storm analysis, and advanced computer modeling are crucial to track these interactions and anticipate possible landfall scenarios.Several notable cases demonstrate the effects of storm interaction:These examples underscore the unpredictable nature of the Fujiwhara Effect and its ability to significantly influence storm behavior, including paths, intensities, and potential impacts on coastal regions.Meteorologists note that both Humberto (Invest 93L) and Invest 94L (Imelda) have a high likelihood of developing further in the coming days. While Humberto may largely remain at sea, 94L could bring heavy rainfall, strong winds, and potential flooding to the Southeast or Mid-Atlantic US coasts.Even if 94L stays offshore, atmospheric conditions may channel moisture inland, creating flash flood risks in areas such as the Carolinas, southern Appalachians, and parts of the Mid-Atlantic starting this weekend. Due to the potential Fujiwhara interaction, tracking these systems closely is critical. Small shifts in position or intensity could dramatically change which regions are affected, highlighting the need for constant monitoring from the National Hurricane Center and local authorities.The Fujiwhara Effect is not just a meteorological curiosity; it has real-world implications for safety and preparedness:The potential interaction between Humberto and Invest 94L serves as a reminder of how complex and dynamic tropical storm behavior can be, particularly when multiple systems form close to each other.

Upon reaching this proximity, the storms begin to orbit a shared central point, creating a ‚Äúdancing‚Äù motion. In rarer cases, storms of nearly equal strength can merge, forming a single, more powerful cyclone. Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.

Article Title: Nvidia‚Äôs Blackwell chips double AI training speed, MLCommons benchmark shows
Article Text: Nvidia‚Äôs newest Blackwell chips have significantly advanced the training of large artificial intelligence systems, dramatically reducing the number of chips needed to train massive language models, new data released Wednesday shows.The results, published by MLCommons, a nonprofit that issues benchmark performance results for AI systems, detail improvements across chips from Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), among others, Reuters reported.The benchmarks focus on AI training ‚Äî the phase where systems learn from vast datasets ‚Äî which remains a key competitive frontier despite the market‚Äôs growing focus on AI inference, or responding to user queries.One major finding was that Nvidia and its partners were the only ones to submit data for training a large-scale model like Llama 3.1 405B, an open-source AI system from Meta Platforms with trillions of parameters. This model is complex enough to stress test modern chips and expose their true training capabilities.According to the data, Nvidia‚Äôs new Blackwell chips are more than twice as fast per chip as the previous-generation Hopper chips.In the fastest result, a cluster of 2,496 Blackwell chips completed the training task in just 27 minutes. By contrast, more than three times that number of Hopper chips was needed to match or better that performance.At a press conference, Chetan Kapoor, chief product officer at CoreWeave ‚Äî which collaborated with Nvidia on the benchmark tests ‚Äî highlighted a broader industry trend.‚ÄúUsing a methodology like that, they're able to continue to accelerate or reduce the time to train some of these crazy, multi-trillion parameter model sizes,‚Äù Kapoor said, referring to a shift from massive monolithic systems to modular training infrastructures made up of smaller chip groups.The benchmark results underline Nvidia‚Äôs dominance in the AI training space, even as rivals like China‚Äôs DeepSeek claim competitive performance with fewer chips. As the race to power ever-larger AI systems intensifies, chip efficiency in training tasks remains a critical metric.
Article Summary: N Nvidia‚Äôs new Blackwell chips are more than twice as fast per chip as the previous-generation Hopper chips, new data shows.
